pros: Great benefits, pay is good. Organizational orientation was good. Nice educational benefits. There is an Advanced Practice Provider group that provided leadership for PAs and NPs.
cons: Department and job specific orientation was terrible. No one has time to train new people. My first three months with the organization, I had zero feedback. There was no orientation procedure, or guidelines. I had changed specialities and the department was well aware of that. In my interview they assured me there would be "plenty" of training. I was given the bare minimum of guidance on what had to be done in a day, but absolutely no education on surgical topics. Anything I learned I taught myself. It was an environment of every person for themselves. Coworkers were overworked and not motivated to assist new hires. Surgeons were unkind, some were downright childish and arguably unprofessional. 4 months into the job, the brand new lead APP decided that weekly quizzes on random topics, with no recommendations on what to focus studies on in addition to weekly oral presentations. Lead APP literally stood over me while I worked.

pros: Loved remote work! Didn't have to see anyone!

She never provided support it got to the point my mental health was suffering, causing my physical health to deteriorate quickly. No one got a long at all. There was so much backstabbing and mistrust among everyone, it just got exhausting. My supervisor left on vacation the first day of a key summer moment and left me totally unprepared on how to process things. I was told the ONLY person I could go to in order to ask questions was the director of the department, which seemed like overkill. Then someone else told me they could help me and then I got in trouble for them offering to help. WTF??? SO much micromanaging, it just became all too much. Too much disorder and pure insanity. Had to save myself from ending up in a mental institution - for real. Not a joke.. It was this dysfunctional. JUST RUN AWAY FROM ANY OF THE UNIVERISTY OF COLORADO JOBS!!!! So many other university and colleges are so much better administratively.

review_title: Loved the environment and the people, administration can be a bit, well, bureaucratic.
pros: Of course, it is a great place to be. Wonderful location. Generally -- depending largely on the department you are in -- the people are enthusiastic and caring. And, there are terrific opportunities to work on innovative projects and be innovative yourself. Great place for an undergraduate to get a jump start on their career. Also, look for mid-career opportunities in interesting, unusual roles.
cons:
As with every employer, there are politics to be played. These vary wildly by department, group and even professor/mentor. Research your prospective department and especially your mentor very careful. Ask questions: make sure your mentor is a service leader, interested in helping you succeed as well as seeing their own projects succeed. Many are like this... many are not. 

Also, be wary of the administration. If you think they have made an error in contracts, etc., pound on doors until it is resolved. It will come back to haunt you -- even years later -- if you don't fix it now.

review_title: Lots of egos and lots of politics
pros: Fellow staff were friendly and nice.  Hours were good, and the vacation time was ample for professional staff.
cons:
I preface this by saying I had never worked for a university before.  I worked  for the Law School as professional staff.  I found there to be a huge divide between faculty and staff, with the ego of several faculty bordering on arrogance.  They treated most staff like they didn't have a brain.  Also, it became apparent that competency wasn't the most important thing, but loyalty to the Dean was.  There are several people that are clearly in way over their head, but what mattered most was they played the game right, and their loyalty could be counted on, not that they knew how to do their job.  

There was little in the way of camaraderie or working together, most people just retreat to their cubicles or office space and buy themselves in the computer.  Most departments are very competitive trying to make themselves look good at the expense of someone else.

review_title: Beautiful place to work...and I wish I was still there
pros:
The people and the atmosphere are the best reasons to work here.  First off, the location is amazing and the weather is generally great.

But, that's superficial, how is it to work there?  Well, as with most universities, there is a bureaucracy. Compared to other places (business, government), though, you'll find that CU is actually fairly efficient.  Sure, you'll get angry at someone in the chain, but on either side of them are people who enjoy their job and will help you.

The benefits were also very nice. Best of all was a pass for RTD. You pay a subsidized price for it, but it's much cheaper than if you bought it yourself, and the bus system in Boulder is quite good in most respects.
cons:
Well, the health benefits weren't great, but I suppose that's the case many places.  The on-campus Health Center is hit-and-miss with a bit too many misses for my comfort.

Plus, being a state institution, it can be aggravating to be at the whim of the legislature. But that goes with the territory as well.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Boulder, CO
pros: From teaching, research, mentorship, and a fairly laissez faire attitude towards course design and implementation - at least in my department - there is an unbelievable amount of autonomy and ownership.   In this, academic culture can be a kind of blessing.
cons: That same openness can lead to a lack of direction, proper evaluation, or even care from colleagues and administration.    Indeed, the isolation of silo mentality is real.   Intradepartmental  politics are real as well and just as unsavory.     We are constantly informed about collegiality and how our mission is the same as is the treatment of all, yet there are clear stratifications within all departments (TT, NTT, Instructor, Adjunct, etc).    It's not a shock that there is lip-service, but it is a "con" to be in an environment where you are told all are equal, yet it's glaring clear that is not the case.

review_title: A great place to live, but a difficult place to work.
pros: Location, location, location.  There are few places on Earth where you can work at a Research 1 university, live in the mountains, commute by public transportation, and ski powder for at least 6 months a year.  The University itself is informal and everyone here understands the importance of having time out of the office.  The campus is also pleasing to the eye and well-maintained. The grants office is very effective.
cons: Salaries are extremely low compared to peer (and lesser) institutions.  The state offers virtually no support for higher education.  The quality of students is poor.  We are severely understaffed, and receive little administrative support.  We are strapped for space, and much of the workspaces are in poor condition.  Simple tasks, because they are unsupported, become big problems.  And new internal and state rules make performing my job very difficult at times.  There is a level of disinterest in supporting the tasks I have been hired to do that is breathtaking.

review_title: Find some sort of financing other than being a TA if you come here for grad school
pros: I love the campus at CU, and teaching is a blast.  The undergraduate population isn't the sharpest I've experienced, but every class I taught has always had one or two students who really engage with the material and make teaching a bit easier.
cons: They don't pay a living wage.  Rent in Boulder is around 900 per month for a 400 square-foot single-bedroom unit, and teaching assistants receive, on average, anywhere from 900 to 1,300 dollars per month.  You do the math.  Sure, your tuition gets remitted, but what does it matter if you have to take out loans to cover living expenses like, say, food?  I'm going to leave CU with a doctorate and a mountain of debt to go along with it, thanks to these policies.

review_title: A mixed bag:  some wonderful, dedicated employees but infrastructure is shoddy and state financing is skimpy.

These fees pay for silly things, such as: being a [insert major here] major (not covered by tuition?), building an enormous buffalo-shaped pool at the rec center, bike service (whether or not you own a bike), computing services (whether or not you use them), etc

review_title: Great place to work in Colorado
pros: The university of Colorado offers a great benefit package depending on what track you are on.  Research and faculty track employees have amazing retirement contributions. cons: PARA employees are limited in their advancement, pay increases and retirement contributions.  Other employees can be promoted and get larger pay increases. If you don't negotiate a good pay grade when you start it is hard to make it up.

cons:
Its pretty hard to get in, but it is worth it once you do. Also, changing departments can be very hard.
The housing prices are very high close to the campus, so plan on a bit of a commute. And you'll want to learn the bus system quickly because parking at CU is terrible, absolutely terrible.

cons: Although the faculty were very helpful and available many of my graduate student peers were absent.  Overall, there could have been more focus on building a sense of community among the graduate researchers.

review_title: Graduate studies in the Molecular Biology program. Overwhelmingly positive, but that largely depends on the lab you join
job_title: Doctoral Research Assistant in Aurora, CO
pros: This campus is growing, with great clinical collaborations available. I loved the open floor plan of the research buildings, and had strong program support.
cons: Your experience can be very negative if you join a lab with a mentor that is not available often. Your experience also differs depending on the program you join. Aurora isn't the best area, and you're many hours from skiing.

review_title: Reasonable employer for just out of college
pros: Good retirement, vacation, sick benefits. Have been great with the need for a flexible schedule. Makes a good springboard for getting into medical/ nursing schools or into other medical disciplines.
cons: Pay tends to be pretty lousy, but that often depends on the individual lab or organization you are working for. Dealing with the administrative burden can be pretty trying.

review_title: A Great Place to Work and Grow
pros: The University of Colorado (CU) was a great place to work and provided me with substantial growth opportunities over my career. Being an institution of higher education, there are differences between being part of System Administration and  working on a campus. I worked within System Administration, so my comments are primarily focused there.
cons: CU provides a tuition benefit for employees and their dependents, but it is more limited than other universities. In addition, the salaries fall below some peers but the total compensation is very competitive.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Worked as a grad researcher in a remote sensing lab. I think the experience is defined by the prof who runs the lab. Mine was great. Challenging but appropriate workload, really cool projects that pushed boundaries. The experience with management of the University never was an issue it all was pretty seamless.
cons: Like with most of academic research the budgets were tight and equipment old, but nothing that was totally hindering the work.

job_title: Peer Career Advisor in Boulder, CO
pros: weekly 1;1's with supervisor—you always knew where you stood, what was going well and what areas you could improve in. A lot of group brainstorming sessions and you were constantly learning from one another. Dynamic role, freedom to design the presentations you were passionate about giving and your voice was always heard.
cons: Hourly wages so it was challenging to support myself on this job alone. Other than that this was an incredible experience so not many cons at all!

pros: Good pay, but great benefits.  Best retirement plan as an employee of the state of Colorado.  Challenging, and yet interesting.  Once people start here, they tend to stay for a very long time.
cons: You tend to stagnate in the same role due to budget constraints, even though you generally will get pay raises every year, except when times are tough, such as during the recession.  Sometimes there's crunch time, but generally overtime is not expected.

review_title: Most positive, although compensation is low and they waste government dollars.
job_title: Professional Research Assistant in Denver, CO
pros: It allows employees to pursue additional education and most managers are flexible with schedules to allow attending classes. The benefits package like insurance coverage and sick days and time off was generous.
cons: The compensation is low compared to corporate positions and it is a government agency so you have to deal with the red tape and aspects of government work. Plus employees have to pay for parking which is a little ridiculous.

review_title: CU is a fairly neutral place to work
pros: Medical and dental benefits are decent here.  My experience has been in the research labs where some areas receive good support, some areas do not.
cons: For some of the academic positions, there is no reasonable way to contribute to a retirement plan and have the University match that at any level.  This is not true at all universities so it is worth considering.

review_title: Hard work for little pay, but excellent experience
pros: If you are trying to support yourself as a graduate student, CU has some great possibilities. There are excellent people here, and many programs allow you to take on a lot of responsibility and learn as you work.
cons: As any grad program, the balance between work and pay is pretty brutal. Little to no feedback on teaching performance, little collaboration among colleagues, and few possibilities for advancement within the grad teaching system.

review_title: Working with Program Council was life changing.
job_title: Student Marketing Director in Boulder, CO
pros:
Learn the ropes of the music industry while working with a passionate group of students that want to put on a good show for the student population.

A stepping stone into getting involved in the local music scene.
cons: You will be managing shows until the early morning, but it wasn't a big issue for me.

pros: Great benefits, lots of professional development opportunities, many lovely and hardworking coworkers, legislated pay increases for classified employees and sometimes the Regents will allow additional, good IT, great Ecopass price, and nice location. One of the few places you will see predominantly female leadership. There are many inspiring educators and practitioners who are doing great work and helping improve lives. Some of them are truly beautiful human beings!
cons:
They say nurses "eat their young." Depending on the work unit the culture can be somewhat inspiring all the way to incredibly toxic. I started in a decent department, but the culture shifted until it became normal for a supervisor to yell at employees in public.
The College of Nursing leadership has struggled with balancing the numerous huge egos and cliques. Many professors aspire to be prestigious, and many of the employees are well educated and intellectual, but are also often emotionally immature, (in-fighting, gossiping, lacking self-awareness, micro-aggressing). Despite cultural competency curricula, and being touted as a caring profession, the faculty can be very narrow in their experiences, so homophobia and xenophobia are a thing. They are savvy enough to talk the diversity lingo (and avoid lawsuits) but they do not promote diversity in practice, and are mostly conservative middle-class white women who don't seem to realize how out of touch they are with their students, let alone their patients.

review_title: Want to be overworked and underpaid? This is your dream job.
pros: Flexible workplace. Benefits are ok.
cons: Pay is far, far below the average in our field. Most PRAs only take these jobs looking to apply to med/graduate school. PIs expect top-quality committed and passionate people, who will be available at all hours of the day and night and on weekends to run experiments and check on equipment. CU pays highly qualified researchers less than administrative assistants make at firms in Denver. Many PI's are very poor managers. Lack of room for advancement. Benefits are mediocre- not nearly good enough to compensate for low pay.

review_title: The good, the bad, and the ugly
job_title: Professional Exempt Staff in London, England
pros:
In my position, there are a few great things:
Flexibility in work hours/ work location (good directors have probably allowed for this)
Great connection with coworkers- longstanding relationships and friendships
Coworkers really support one another - there is a good team sense and support system within office (this is what keeps me at CU)
Most prof exempt coworkers work hard - pull their weight
Make lots of 'friends' within department due to nature of longevity for employees
Have a lot of good clients, although some faculty need to let go of their egos
Good vacation/sick leave/etc. 
Casual environment
cons:
Very undervalued, supported and appreciated by higher management (if didn't have office support- wouldn't be a great place to be as the office makes up for this) -leadership's favorite word is "no"

Horrible pay - NO pay raises (even with consistent stellar reviews which allow for highest pay raise percentage - this is for professional exempt positions- don't know about faculty positions

No opportunity for growth in current office - no where to move up to as we are not an academic dept

State employees- don't work, but can't fire them, just have to wait until they retire
Dept is too tied to the state system - need to separate from the state more

Benefits have gone downhill and gotten more expensive over the last 10 years - have lost some benefits as the State has declared them "perks"

Extremely bureaucratic, which makes doing your job well very frustrating - even when you have 'learned how to navigate the system'

No buy-in for services rendered to the public as university system is too large and fragmented with each area having its own vested interests and direction

Academic people 'running' a business - (which has proven itself to not be a good idea) -

pros: Great co workers, great staff morale, great PI's and researchers.  time off policies, flexible work hours.  I loved learning more and more about medical testing, behavior testing and all the fantastic things that these people do. I loved how the care techs and vet techs cared more about the health and safety of all of the animals more then the peoples research. If a mouse was super sick or something we did everything possible to help the mouse or whatever animal.
cons: It was hard to euthanize mice.

review_title: It has been a good challenge and very fulfilling
pros: The benefits and location are very good. If you want the opportunity to advance your career and work in a fast paced and growing company this is a good place for you.
cons: You must work hard, which can be a con to some people but if you want to feel that you have accomplished something at the end of the day then this is a good place.

review_title: Excellent University with excellent people, in a beautiful part of the US
job_title: Senior Professional Research Assistant in Boulder, CO
pros: Boulder, CO is an absolutely amazing town for the outdoor oriented mountain lover.  University of Colorado, Boulder is a very solid academic university and treats their employees well.  The campus is beautiful.
cons: I worked as a post-doc and the only downside is that post-doc positions, by nature, have to end sometime.  I have nothing bad to say about CU-Boulder, whatsoever.

review_title: Review of University of Colorado Boulder
pros: University of Colorado Boulder is a fine place to work and Boulder is a great city to live in.  Although Colorado provides almost no state funding to its "public" universities, they thrive.
cons: Everyone here has a vision, and sometimes it's difficult to resolve conflicts among staff.  Boulder is like the Bay Area, but with mountains, and with costs of living only about half the Bay Area....

pros:
High degree of freedom in doing your job. 
Laid-back research environment. 
Brilliant professors/graduate students to work with.
Boulder, CO itself is the best incentive.
cons:
Very bureaucratic as a public research university; things move slowly especially when university administration is involved.
Quite political among professors, at least in the department that I work for.
Lack sense of teamwork.
Tight budgets and low pay as a result. House renting in Boulder is skyrocketing thanks to Google.

pros: Great benefits and work, life balance.  Great advancement opportunities with three different campuses. Organization has a great reputation and there is good training in place.
cons: Sometimes it's too slow and not enough work. Pay is less than private industry.  Organization seems to lack good communication between campuses.   Management sometimes does not listen to lower level people for advice before moving forward with new processes.

pros: Pros are ver food benefits, including vacation and sick time, PERA retirement, good health plan, dental and vision.
cons: Cons are that even at the lowest level of job, they require a college degree. Working downtown for the Denver office is that it is difficult to get to, and parking is $120 per month, right out of your paycheck.

review_title: I would not suggest working at UCCS.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Working with students is a great experience. They love to learn and are eager to assist with daily tasks.
cons: Although it is great that the campus is growing, the staff is not. Upper management piles on more and more work to the same amount of staff and expects excellent results from an extremely overworked and extremely underpaid staff.

pros: CU Anschutz is top-tier for research, with all the cutting edge technologies. People here are friendly, collaborative, and always willing to help. The research going on here is very cool and translational since the hospitals are right next door.

review_title: Great place to work as a student

pros: You are in Boulder, one of the most beautiful cities in the US. University of Colorado has a great reputation and I'm proud to work here.  Boulder also has a fantastic infrastructure for fitness and athletics.
